facts.text: Elections held on five days in December 1951 and January 1952 for two seats in Bhandara Parliamentary Constituency.
Thirteen candidates filed nomination papers, including the petitioner. Six contested the seat reserved for Scheduled Castes (Mahar caste).
Gangaram Thaware filed nomination for reserved seat. Born a Mahar, later joined Mahanubhava Panth. Objection: ceased to be Mahar. Nomination rejected.
Another Scheduled Caste candidate's nomination rejected; five others withdrawn, including present petitioner. Left six candidates, three eligible for reserved seat.
Elected: Tularam Sakhare (Scheduled Caste seat), Chaturbhuj Jasani (general seat).

Election Petition No. 3 of 1952 filed challenging Jasani's election on ground of disqualification under Section 7(d) Representation of the People Act 1951 (interest in contract for supply of goods to Central Government).
Election Tribunal, Nagpur, by judgment dated 15th July 1953: Rejection of Thaware's nomination improper (continued Mahar); Jasani disqualified (contract with Government); set aside whole election.
Jasani partner in Moolji Sicka Company, bidi manufacturers. Firm had arrangement with Canteen Stores (Government) for supply of bidis to troops via canteens.
Arrangement via letters: Firm sells to Canteen Stores/contractors, pays commission to Government. Rs. 7,500 paid in settlement pre-dates.

Tabular statement (Exhibit C): Orders placed/accepted between 8-10-1951 and 23-1-1952, invoices, despatches, payments post crucial dates (15-11-1951 nomination, 14-2-1952 declaration). Outstanding contracts worth lakhs between dates.
Correspondence from 30-3-1951: Direct Supply System, then proposals for Consignment System (pay as sold, return unsold within 6 months), accepted 9-8-1951.
Consignment contracts to Bombay/Delhi/Calcutta depots Oct 1951, obligations continued to Apr 1952.
Gangaram Thaware married twice to Mahar girls (non-Mahanubhavas initially); led Mahar agitations; contested 1936 as Mahar; declared himself Mahar in nomination verification.
No evidence of outcasting from Mahars upon joining Mahanubhava Panth; witnesses (Mahars) say retains caste, inter-marries, participates in functions.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether Chaturbhuj Jasani disqualified under Section 7(d) Representation of the People Act 1951 for interest in contract for supply of goods to Central Government.
Whether Gangaram Thaware ceased to be a Mahar upon joining Mahanubhava Panth, justifying rejection of nomination for Scheduled Caste seat.
Whether contracts subsisted on crucial dates (15-11-1951, 14-2-1952) despite supply/despatch, until payment.
Whether contracts void under Article 299(1) Constitution for not expressed/made in President's name.

petitioner_arguments.text: No binding contract from letters; merely readiness to do business; each order separate contract; no subsisting contract on crucial dates as goods supplied before.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rose and Frank Co. v. J. R. Crompton Bros. Ltd.

petitioner_arguments.text: Contract terminates upon full execution (supply); becomes debtor-creditor; no interest in contract post-supply.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: English cases like Royse v. Birley, Tranton v. Astor

petitioner_arguments.text: Contracts not in form under Article 299(1); void.
Thaware ceased to be Mahar upon joining Mahanubhava Panth which rejects caste.

respondent_arguments.text: Arrangement constituted continuing contract; commission obligation; orders placed/accepted created contracts subsisting till payment.
Contract continues till fully discharged by both sides; interest persists till payment.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Satyendrakumar Das v. Chairman of Municipal Commissioners

respondent_arguments.text: Thaware continued Mahar; no outcasting; retains social ties, marriages, leadership.

court_reasoning.text: Letters created continuing arrangement for commission; individual orders separate contracts but subsisting between crucial dates per Exhibit C.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Contracts outstanding worth Rs. 84,659 pre-15-11-1951 unpaid; further Rs.39,695 between dates.

court_reasoning.text: Consignment System accepted 9-8-1951: pay as sold, replace unsold within 6 months; obligation to supply replacements is contract term.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Guarantee clause part of contract for supply.

court_reasoning.text: Contract continues till fully performed by both sides (payment); not mere debtor-creditor.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Vendor may sue on contract if payment disputed.

court_reasoning.text: Not void under Article 299(1); applies to protect Government from unauthorised acts; innocent party protected under Contract Act s.230; Government not suable but contracts effective.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Technical defect does not void; purpose purity of legislature.

court_reasoning.text: Conversion to Mahanubhava Panth nominal; no outcasting by Mahars; Thaware retained ties, marriages, leadership; regarded as Mahar.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Practical social consequences over theology; Abraham v. Abraham principles apply.

holdings.text: Jasani had share/interest in subsisting contracts for supply of goods to Government on crucial dates; disqualified under s.7(d) RPA 1951.
Contracts not void under Art.299(1); hit s.7(d) as for supply to Government.
Thaware continued member of Mahar caste despite joining Mahanubhava Panth; nomination rejection improper.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rose and Frank Co. v. J. R. Crompton Bros. Ltd.
Satyendrakumar Das v. Chairman of the Municipal Commissioners of Dacca

precedents_cited.relevance: Principles on convert retaining old law ties.

precedents_cited.case_name: Collector of Masulipatam v. Cavaly Venkata Narrainapah
precedents_cited.relevance: Government bound if ratifies excess authority.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Disqualification if share/interest in contract for supply of goods to Government.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Contracts by Government to be expressed/made by President; technical non-compliance does not void for third parties.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Protection for innocent contracting party with Government; compensation claims.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed. Tribunal correctly held Jasani disqualified under s.7(d) due to subsisting contracts with Government; also correctly held Thaware remained Mahar, so nomination rejection improper. Election set aside upheld.

key_quotes.text: "A person shall be disqualified for being chosen as... if by himself he has any share or interest in a contract for the supply of goods to the appropriate Government."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.7(d) RPA central to Jasani issue.

key_quotes.text: "We hold therefore that these contracts which Moolji Sicka Company had entered into with the Government subsisted on 15th November, 1951, and on 14th February, 1952."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Conversion to this sect imports little beyond an intellectual acceptance of certain ideological tenets and does not alter the convert's caste status."
key_quotes.speaker: court
